author: Chris Kitching for MailOnline
title: K2 set to become the next Everest as commercial expeditions begin for $60k
text:
9 shares 1
View
comments
Once reserved for the elite, the world’s most dangerous mountain is opening up to more climbers thanks to guided tours that are charging a small fortune.
Even though it’s the world’s second-highest peak behind Mount Everest, K2 is regarded as a much harder ascent due to its treacherous terrain and nasty weather conditions.
While less experienced climbers can reach Everest’s summit if they have the money, K2 is considered a far more exclusive conquest, although it may soon lose some of that lustre as it becomes commercialised for the first time.
Set on the China-Pakistan border, K2 is regarded as the most dangerous mountain in the world
This year, two reputable firms offered expeditions with professional guides and Sherpas at a cost of nearly $60,000 (£40,000), promising to take experienced climbers to the summit as long as weather and route conditions cooperated.
They plan to return again next year, with London-based Himalayan Experience offering a 67-day trek at a cost of $55,000 (£36,000).
Paying to scale the ‘Savage Mountain’ with guides and Sherpas doesn’t diminish the risk, however, as climbers put their lives on the line to be among the few to achieve mountaineering glory.
Set on the China-Pakistan border, the 28,251ft peak is feared for its extreme difficulty, and is one of the deadliest with one death for every four summits.

Himalayan Experience’s expedition is open to 12 people, who will be accompanied by four guides and Sherpas, although it is only open to climbers with at least two previous 8,000 metre (26,246ft) summits, including Everest.
Seattle-based Madison Mountaineering is the other company offered guided expeditions, with its $58,500 (£38,500) trip expected to last as long as 60 days.
But the cost for both trips will be higher, as the packages do not include expenses such as return airfare to Pakistan, extra hotel nights, and bonuses for Sherpas.
While those companies reserve their spaces for veteran climbers, there is a risk that others who follow in their footsteps may not.
K2 is a much tougher climb than Mount Everest (pictured) because the terrain and weather is much worse
Mick Conefrey, an Oxford-based author and documentary filmmaker who has written a book on the first climbers to reach K2’s summit, doesn’t think commercialised tours will bring the same large-scale climbing that Everest has because the mountain is so difficult to conquer.
If anything, it will raise the profile of the mountain, which will remain a badge of honour, he said.
He told MailOnline Travel: ‘It will be more of a niche, but people will still see it as a huge challenge.
‘It will become more accessible, but I don’t think you’ll have novices ever saying “I’m going to climb K2”.’
Mr Conefrey is the author of The Ghosts of K2, which documents early attempts to climb the remote mountain and the saga of the first successful ascent.
In 1954, Achille Compagnoni and Lino Lacedelli accomplished what many tried to do before them when they reached the peak.
Mr Conefrey has visited K2 to film a documentary, but has not attempted to reach its summit.
Author and documentary filmmaker Mick Conefrey has written a book on the first climbers to reach K2's peak
He said the mountain is considered the toughest in the world because its steeper terrain is varied, with some spots covered in avalanche-prone snow and others in ice and rock.
The weather tends to be much worse than Everest, it is a much more technical climb and it’s very hard to find campsites on the way up, he added.
In some years, no one has reached the summit.
Mr Conefrey said: ‘Because of all those factors for years there wasn’t really the same kind of commercial expeditions that you get on Everest.
‘There were no companies offering packages to climbers where they would have a high level of support, with a lot of Sherpa and guide assistance.
‘The sort of commercial operators who work on Everest regularly just weren’t in the K2 game because it was thought there wouldn’t be the demand because it’s so much harder than Everest.
‘[Guided expeditions] are something nobody really expected because K2 was seen as being in a different league.’
